display_asset.caption: Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center was attacked by hackers this month.

summaries.body: A Los Angeles hospital paid a ransom of about $17,000 to hackers who had used a malware attack to hold the hospital's computer system hostage.

display_asset.caption: A woman posing for wedding photos on the Shanghai riverfront. The Communist Party’s antigraft commission has issued instructions to officials on avoiding extravagance at weddings and funerals.

summaries.body: Is the guest list too long? That's one of the questions that Communist Party officials in China must ponder when planning weddings or funerals as part of an antigraft effort.

display_asset.caption: Angela Raiola, a.k.a. Big Ang of “Mob Wives,” in January.

summaries.body: Angela Raiola, the reality TV star known as “Big Ang” on the VH1 show “Mob Wives,” died Thursday of complications of cancer, the show's creator said. She was 55.

display_asset.caption: The relatives of victims of a car bombing in Ankara, Turkey, mourned outside a morgue on Thursday.

summaries.body: The Turkish government said that a car bombing that killed 28 people in the capital, Ankara, a day earlier had been carried out by a member of Syrian Kurdish militia.

display_asset.caption: Charlie Beck, the Los Angeles police chief, discussed the sexual assault accusations against two of the department’s police officers at a news conference on Wednesday.

summaries.body: Two Los Angeles police officers have been charged with repeatedly sexually assaulting four women over the course of more than two years, prosecutors said.

display_asset.caption: Manny Pacquiao, who is running for a senate seat in the Philippines, at a campaign event this month.

summaries.body: Nike has terminated its relationship with Manny Pacquiao, the boxer, after he called people in gay relationships “worse than animals.”

display_asset.caption: A RAV4, right, in Tokyo. Toyota said that the seatbelts themselves were safe and that the problem was not caused by a supplier.

summaries.body: Toyota recalled nearly three million RAV4 sport utility vehicles worldwide, saying their rear seatbelts could be severed in a severe crash.
A moody image depicting the hardship of the migration crisis has been named the winner of the World Press Photo Contest. The New York Times also won five awards.
A female inmate on death row in Vietnam impregnated herself with sperm bought from another inmate in an apparent effort to avoid execution, a state-owned newspaper reports.

display_asset.caption: Confederate flag supporters during a rally in Stone Mountain, Ga., last year.

summaries.body: Hate groups are on the rise. The Southern Poverty Law Center said the number of groups organized against racial, religious, sexual or other characteristics rose by 14 percent.

display_asset.caption: Malachi A. Love-Robinson

summaries.body: A Florida teenager has been accused of posing as a doctor. Again. The arrest of Malachi A. Love-Robinson, 18, is the latest in a series of encounters with law enforcement.

display_asset.caption: Jason Casares in 2014.

summaries.body: The associate dean who oversees sexual misconduct cases at Indiana University faces sexual assault accusations of his own.
After Jeb Bush tweeted the word "America" and a photo of a gun, Mayor Bill de Blasio responded on Wednesday with the same word and a photo of a Carnegie Deli sandwich.
Why do teenage girls roll their eyes? The mannerism serves a variety of purposes, and it tells us a lot about what it’s like to be a teenager, Lisa Damour writes.

display_asset.caption: Students protested last October at the University of Texas at Austin to oppose a state law allowing the concealed carry of handguns on campuses.
display_asset.credit: Ralph Barrera/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press

summaries.body: The University of Texas has set parameters for concealed handguns on campus to comply with state law. The school's president said he still disagreed with the law.

display_asset.caption: David Bostick, 71, at home in Pittsburgh. After a few weeks of smearing a gel on his stomach — he did not know if it was testosterone or a placebo — he began to feel better. He correctly guessed that he was getting testosterone.
display_asset.credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times

summaries.body: Testosterone gel has some modest benefits for men in terms of sexual functioning, but little else, according to researchers.

display_asset.caption: A Taliban fighter in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in September. The United Nations has documented that children as young as 10 were used by the Taliban in the battle for Kunduz.

summaries.body: The Taliban used child soldiers in last year's battle to overrun the northern city of Kunduz in Afghanistan, a human rights group said. The government later retook the city.

display_asset.caption: The ancient fortress called Naryn-Kala, which dominates Derbent, Russia. Many in the town are convinced that the Kremlin lopped 3,000 years off Derbent’s age to avoid having a Muslim city named the oldest urban settlement in a country that presents itself as the defender of traditional Christian values.
display_asset.credit: James Hill for The New York Times

summaries.body: Derbent was planning to celebrate its 5,000th anniversary, claiming the title of Russia's oldest city. Then Moscow knocked 3,000 years off its age.

display_asset.caption: The Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho.

summaries.body: The Metropolitan Opera is to stage its first opera by a woman since 1903. The 2016-17 season includes a work by the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho.

display_asset.caption: The radio telescope under construction in Guizhou Province. The building project, known as FAST, is estimated to cost about $184 million.

summaries.body: China is relocating thousands of villagers in Guizhou Province to build a $184 million telescope for detecting signs of extraterrestrial life.

display_asset.caption: Steve Spagnuolo will remain the Giants’ defensive coordinator on Coach Ben McAdoo’s staff, which features familiar names.

summaries.body: The Giants announced that 12 assistant coaches from the former coach Tom Coughlin’s staff had been retained, including Steve Spagnuolo, the defensive coordinator.

display_asset.caption: Killer Mike at a rally for Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, in Atlanta.
display_asset.credit: Kevin D. Liles for The New York Times

summaries.body: Killer Mike, a rapper, ignited a controversy after he said that “a uterus doesn’t qualify you to be president” during an event hosted by Senator Bernie Sanders in Atlanta.
A report questions the authenticity of several brands of Parmesan cheese after it was found that one company’s “100 percent real” product was filled with wood pulp.
A man stole $26,000 from two women he met separately on Tinder, telling them he urgently needed to borrow money to pay medical bills for relatives.

display_asset.caption: Paul Aker of Houston said armed deputy marshals showed up at his door over an old student debt.

summaries.body: United States marshals showed up at the house of a Houston man who had failed to repay a $1,500 student loan that was almost 30 years old.

display_asset.caption: A scene from Marco Bellocchio’s Roman Inquisition piece, “Blood of My Blood.”

summaries.body: Retrospective period films continue to capture critics' imaginations, dominating the annual festival for Film Comment, the magazine of Lincoln Center's film society.

display_asset.caption: Manny Pacquiao, an eight-time world boxing champion who is running for senator in the Philippines, speaking to supporters in May.

summaries.body: Manny Pacquiao, the boxer turned Philippine politician, apologized after calling people in gay relationships "worse than animals."
Nigerian women and girls freed from Boko Haram are facing rejection when they return home, a report found, because of stigma about rape and fear of radicalization.

display_asset.credit: Matthew Staver for The New York Times

summaries.body: Levels of omega-3 fatty acids, beneficial for lowering the risk of heart disease, were 50 percent higher in organic meat and milk, a review of scientific studies reported.

display_asset.caption: Neel Kashkari was a Treasury Department official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations.

summaries.body: A top architect of the 2008 federal bailout of the financial industry said "banks are still too big to fail" and that the government had not done enough to prevent a repeat.
